channel.title: Racial slurs
channel.description:
Let's continue our conversation about the use of these words here.
It's getting the other thread majorly off-topic.
The way Nas uses the word nigger is as a commentary on racism. He's embracing the term as a mark of defiance against oppression from politicians and music industry censors. That context makes it acceptable. Using the word purely as a slur, to represent a group of people based on their behavior and clothing, is the very use he is protesting against.
Douchebag works just as well to refer to unintelligent, materialistic fuckwads. But nigger used in that context is reprehensible and stupid.

item.dc:creator: Diabeetus
item.description:
Its all about context. Sometimes giving attention to things like racial slurs is what gives them power. Sometimes it is best to blow them off, while living in Wailuku, one of the poorest and crime infested cities on Maui, and I was called a “Haole”, even if I was offended I would not show it, it would have served to embolden fights that I had no part in and honestly did not understand.
When someone has used a jewish slur against me I feel the same way, they are showing their ignorance.

item.title: Racial slurs
item.dc:creator: Ballsopt
item.description:
yes, I’m familiar with such social circles. I’ve lived around the states and had a variety of experiences to learn from and form my conclusions. Charleston, SC for example is vastly different from the Mission district in SF. likewise Baton Rouge has parallels to Seattle WA.
As you said, It really just depends where you are. But the 21st century approach is mostly against the perpetuation of not only that word but also the connotations and destructive culture surrounding it (namely the whole “ghetto” lifestyle, which is a vicious generational cycle that is hard for impoverished and misinformed youths to break).
Still, I guess things are gradually getting better.

item.title: Racial slurs
item.dc:creator: raw_bean
item.description:
mattemuse:

My point wasn’t so much “know your audience.” What i am saying is that the “its only words, no word can be offensive” argument boils down to “i’m not offended therefore nobody else has the right to be offended” and it’s a pretty obvious violation of any standard of civilized behavior. Take for example the “draw mohoammad” thread - do something thats offensive to certain people, on the basis that since it’s not offensive to everyone, it should be offensive to no-one. (That’s the charitable explanation - personally I suspect the point is simply to insult muslim beliefs, full stop). Bottom line, no person has any r ight to determine what other people can or can not be offended by.

I never said I was trying to summarise your stance, merely agreeing with it and saying that it lead to (‘hence’) my stance as offered. Since I don’t have to right to to determine what other people find to be offensive, I try and avoid behaviour that could offend others even if I or people I know wouldn’t have a problem with it, until I haver a good idea what a given person’s boundaries are.
